--- title: "Other outcome variables" --- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.5 ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.1 ✔ ggplot2 3.5.2 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 ✔ lubridate 1.9.3 ✔ tidyr 1.3.1 ✔ purrr 1.0.2 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} library(kableExtra) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Attaching package: 'kableExtra' The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr': group_rows ``` ::: ::: ## Behavioral measures ### Donation To assess consequential and impactful behavior, participants will be given the option to donate a monetary bonus to the American Geophysical Union (AGU), or keep it for themselves. The AGU was chosen because it is the leading scientific association for scientists working on climate change. Participants read following: > | “For the next question, we would like you to have the opportunity to donate money to a non-profit or to keep it for yourself. Please decide how you would like to allocate $10 between yourself and the American Geophysical Union (AGU). The AGU is a non-profit, non-partisan scientific association. It is the largest scientific association in the area of climate change in the US, with over 15,000 scientist members. You can give all of the money to the AGU and keep none for yourself, or you can keep all the money for yourself and give none to AGU, or you can pick any split in between. Note: We will randomly select a subset of 100 participants and realize their choices. ” \[Slider\] ### Petition \[*to be done*\] ## Normative perceptions & Willingness to be vulnerable [General consideration: normative perceptions, here, really are for the most part about scientists influence on public policy. It would make sense to have a more meaningful, less abstract name.] Scales were adapted from XX, but slightly modified. For example, for the normative perception measure, we removed one item ("Climate scientists should be more involved in the policy-making process") as it was extremely close to the first item of the scale. For the willingness to be vulnerable measure, we retained only one item, as the other two ("How much or little should governments rely on climate scientists’ guidance when making decisions related to climate science?" and "How much or little control do you want climate scientists to have on government decisions related to science?") were very close conceptually to the normative perception measures. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Full table normative_items <- tribble( ~Item, ~Response_Options, # Normative Perceptions of Science and Society "To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?", "", "Climate scientists should work closely with politicians to integrate scientific results into policy-making", "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree", "Climate scientists should actively advocate for specific policies", "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree", "Climate scientists should communicate their findings to politicians", "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree", "Climate scientists should be more involved in the policy-making process", "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree", "Climate scientists should communicate their findings to the general public", "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree", "Climate scientists should remain independent from the policy-making process", "(1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree", # Willingness to be vulnerable to climate scientists "How willing are you to rely on climate scientists’ advice when making lifestyle choices (e.g., sustainable transportation, energy use and nutrition)?", "(1) Not at all, (2) A little, (3) A moderate amount, (4) A lot, (5) A great deal" ) # Display the table normative_items |> kable(col.names = c("Item", "Response Options"), escape = TRUE, longtable = TRUE) |> kable_styling(full_width = FALSE, font_size = 11, position = "center") |> pack_rows("Normative perceptions of climate scientists", 1, 7) |> pack_rows("Willingness to be vulnerable to the advice of climate scientists", 8, 8) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Item Response Options
Normative perceptions of climate scientists
To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?
Climate scientists should work closely with politicians to integrate scientific results into policy-making (1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree
Climate scientists should actively advocate for specific policies (1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree
Climate scientists should communicate their findings to politicians (1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree
Climate scientists should be more involved in the policy-making process (1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree
Climate scientists should communicate their findings to the general public (1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree
Climate scientists should remain independent from the policy-making process (1) Strongly disagree, (2) Disagree, (3) Neither agree nor disagree, (4) Agree, (5) Strongly agree
Willingness to be vulnerable to the advice of climate scientists
How willing are you to rely on climate scientists’ advice when making lifestyle choices (e.g., sustainable transportation, energy use and nutrition)? (1) Not at all, (2) A little, (3) A moderate amount, (4) A lot, (5) A great deal
````` ::: ::: ## Single item trust in climate scientists measures ### U.S. General Social Survey > Would you say you have a great deal of confidence, only some confidence, or hardly any confidence at all in the scientific community of climate scientists? [3 - A great deal; 2 - Only some; 1 - Hardly any] ### TISP Manylabs study Modified version form XX. > To what extent do you trust scientists in your country who work on climate change? [1-Not at all to 5-Very strongly] ## Support for climate policies Modified version from XX. [I think using a 3-point scale here is weird and unnecessary, make alternative suggestion]. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Policy support items policy_items <- tribble( ~Item, ~Response_Options, # Policy support "Please indicate your level of support for the following policies.", "", "Raising carbon taxes on gas and fossil fuels or coal", "(1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable", "Expanding infrastructure for public transportation", "(1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable", "Increasing the use of sustainable energy such as wind and solar energy", "(1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable", "Protecting forested and land areas", "(1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable", "Increasing taxes on carbon intense foods (e.g., beef and dairy products)", "(1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable", ) # Display the table policy_items |> kable(col.names = c("Item", "Response Options"), escape = TRUE, longtable = TRUE) |> kable_styling(full_width = FALSE, font_size = 11, position = "center") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Item Response Options
Please indicate your level of support for the following policies.
Raising carbon taxes on gas and fossil fuels or coal (1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable
Expanding infrastructure for public transportation (1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable
Increasing the use of sustainable energy such as wind and solar energy (1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable
Protecting forested and land areas (1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable
Increasing taxes on carbon intense foods (e.g., beef and dairy products) (1) Not at all – (2) Moderately – (3) Very much – (NA) Not applicable
````` ::: ::: ## Funding \[*to be discussed*\] Adapted from the National [Science Foundation (NSF) – Science & Engineering Indicators](https://ncses.nsf.gov/pubs/nsb20227/public-perceptions-of-science-and-technology#general-perceptions-of-s-t), also used, also used in @ophirFactorsAssessingSciences2023 > Climate change research that advances the frontiers of knowledge is necessary and should be supported by funding from the federal government. \[Strongly disagree - Strongly agree\] ## Belief in climate change from vlasceanu et al 2024 > How accurate do you think this statement is?
